description: From Middle English ple, from Old French plait, plaid, from Medieval Latin placitum (“a decree, sentence, suit, plea, etc., Latin an opinion, determination, prescription, order; literally, that which is pleasing, pleasure”), neuter of placitus, past participle of placere (“to please”). Cognate with Spanish pleito (“lawsuit, suit”). Doublet of placit and placate. See also please, pleasure.

entries.meaning: An appeal, petition, urgent prayer or entreaty.
That which is alleged or pleaded, in defense or in justification.
(law) That which is alleged by a party in support of his cause.
(law) An allegation of fact in a cause, as distinguished from a demurrer.
(law) The defendant’s answer to the plaintiff’s declaration and demand.
(law) A cause in court; a lawsuit; as, the Court of Common Pleas.
examples: they or any three of them shall be a Court and have cognizance of pleas real, personal, and mixed.

verbs.description: plea (third-person singular simple present pleas, present participle pleaing, simple past and past participle pleaed)

entries.meaning: (chiefly England regional, Scotland) To plead; to argue. [from 15th c.]
examples: With my riches, my unhappiness was increased tenfold; and here, with another great acquisition of property, for which I had pleaed, and which I had gained in a dream, my miseries and difficulties were increasing.
